Subject: Denver - Chicago TeraGrid Link Down
Content:
On 2/13 at 11pm Central, the Teragrid link between Denver and Chicago went down.  The outage occurred along a portion of the path that also impacted the first of two backup paths.	That backup path has been rerouted and is now restored.  From 2/13 11pm to 2/14 1030am central, traffic was routed across the second alternative.

During the outage, users may experience reduced capacity when using the network between SDSC or NCAR and the rest of TeraGrid.

The ETR for the primary path is currently 5pm central.

Content:

The next planned maintenance window for Purdue's major systems is May 15 through May 17, 2012. All of our systems will be down for some portion of that time to allow for significant work on the electrical power systems and the file storage systems used by the research clusters.

Steele, the Condor Pool and Wispy will be taken down Tuesday, May 15th at 6:00am, and are currently expected to return to service Thursday, May 17th at 5:00pm.

As always with scheduled maintenance, submitted jobs whose requested walltimes would take them into the maintenance period will be held in the queue until after the system returns to service.

This information is available on our website at "Scheduled Maintenance":http://www.rcac.purdue.edu/news/detail.cfm?NewsID=526 which will be updated if the schedule changes.

Thank you for your support, please don't hesitate to contact us with any questions or concerns at "help@xsede.org":mailto:help@xsede.org

Subject: Stampede System Maintenance 6/25
Content:
Stampede will be unavailable from 7:00 am - 8:00 pm (CT) on Tuesday, June 25, 2013.

During this time, the base Linux operating system will be upgraded from CentOS 6.3 to CentOS 6.4. In addition, the corresponding Intel Xeon Phi software stack will be upgraded to the latest revision to support acceptance testing efforts underway for the Xeon Phi co-processor subsystem.

As a reminder, please recall that Stampede is the first large-scale deployment of Intel's new Xeon Phi co-processors.  The base compute system -- Dell PowerEdge nodes with Xeon E5 (Sandy Bridge) processors, NVIDIA K20 GPUs, Mellanox FDR interconnect, and Lustre file systems -- entered production operation on January 7th.  Since then, the Xeon Phi co-processor subsystem has continued to be deployed with a subset made available to users for early access development and testing. Acceptance testing for for the Xeon Phi co-processor subsystem will continue during June and July and we encourage users to contact TACC consulting with any issues encountered with the latest runtime environment. A follow on announcement will be made when the Xeon Phi subsystem has been formally accepted indicating the availability of the entire subsystem for standard production usage by users.

Please submit any questions you may have via the Consulting section of the XSEDE User Portal.

Subject: SDSC Gordon, Trestles, Data Oasis: Network Infrastructure and Lustre Upgrade
Content:
We will be upgrading the network infrastructure and the Lustre software that supports the Data Oasis filesystems starting 9AM (PT) on March 9, 2014 and ending 9PM (PT) on March 10, 2014. During this upgrade period Trestles, Gordon, and Data Oasis will be unavailable to users. The data mover nodes for Trestles and Gordon will also be unavailable.

In addition to the network upgrade, we will also be upgrading the Lustre server and client software for Data Oasis. The Lustre upgrade will be done without impacting data already in the Data Oasis filesystems. However, we take this opportunity to remind users of best practices while using Data Oasis : 1) Please delete any files that are no longer needed, including duplicates of data sets. This helps with both space availability and performance of the filesystems, 2) The data in the filesystems is *not* backed up. Please back up any critical data offsite. 

We will keep users updated via a news post as we get closer to the upgrade date. Please email help@xsede.org if you have any questions.

Subject: Failover testing of myproxy.xsede.org server NCSA to PSC
Content:
On May 10, 2016 between 11am and noon central time (UTC-05:00), the
XSEDE MyProxy service will undergo failover testing from the primary
myproxy.xsede.org server (hosted at NCSA) to the secondary
myproxy.psc.xsede.org server (hosted at PSC), and back. This will
involve temporarily disabling the network connection to myproxy.xsede.org.

MyProxy clients configured to use both myproxy.xsede.org and
myproxy.psc.xsede.org should not experience any downtime. This includes
the XSEDE User Portal. However, MyProxy clients configured to connect to
myproxy.xsede.org exclusively may experience downtime.

Example myproxy-logon command line using both MyProxy servers:

# myproxy-logon -s myproxy.xsede.org,myproxy.psc.xsede.org
